Award.AwardTitle: International: Identifying strategies to protect biodiversity in rapidly-developing southwest China: Songbird abundance and diversity in Tibetan sacred forests
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Doctoral Dissertation Enhancement Program award supports the field research in China of Ms. Jodi Brandt, whose objective is to identify effective strategies of conservation. The specific project will investigate how Tibetan sacred-forest patches, protected areas, contribute to biodiversity in a very important but highly-threatened biodiversity hotspot, the Himalayan Mountains of Southwest China. She will test the hypothesis that bird diversity and abundance are higher in the sacred forests than in the surrounding landscapes, and that the sacred forests are important keystone structures for the maintenance of regional biodiversity. The research will be performed in Northwest Yunnan Province. PhD student Brandt, under the direction of Dr. Volker Radeloff, will conduct the research in collaboration with two experienced Chinese ecologists, an ornithologist from the Southwest Forestry University and a botanist from the Shangri-la Alpine Botanical Garden. They will survey breeding-bird communities and bird habitat in sacred forests near Shangri-la City, the most developed and rapidly changing region in NW Yunnan.
Despite the importance of NW Yunnan for regional avian biodiversity, no research has been done on forest songbirds in the study area. This research represents a foundational study to understand forest-bird habitat and distribution in this rapidly-changing region. It will explore critical ecological concepts in a unique and unstudied region. Acknowledging sacred areas as an important means to protect biodiversity could ensure their continued existence in the face of accelerating political, socioeconomic, and cultural change and may offer new avenues for conservation in other parts of the world.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Northwest Yunnan, China, in the southern Himalayas, is one of the world's 25 biodiversity hotspots. It is a center of avian endemism in China and on a major bird migration route, but little research had been done on forest songbird distribution, diversity, population trends, or habitat needs. Tibetan sacred forests protect old-growth forests from logging, and these forests and their surrounding degraded and logged forests together encompass a wide range of forested habitats, providing a convenient study design to understand 1) what birds are breeding in different forest types of NW Yunnan, 2) what habitat characteristics the birds are selecting, and 3) the ecological and conservation role of Tibetan sacred forests for avian diversity in our study area.

To answer these questions, we surveyed birds and their habitat in and around six Tibetan sacred forest patches over two years. We found that sacred forests supported a significantly different bird community than surrounding forests, had higher bird abundance, and higher bird species richness. Furthermore, while we encountered a homogeneous bird community outside of the sacred forests, the sacred forest patches supported multiple diverse bird communities. we also identified habitat characteristics important for forest birds. While bird community composition was primarily driven by the vertical structure of the vegetation, forests with the largest trees (height or diameter) and bamboo groves had the highest bird diversity and abundance, indicating the importance of protecting old-growth forest ecosystems for Himalayan forest birds.

Old-growth forest clearing and degradation have accelerated throughout the Himalayas, and our results offer hope for forest birds, because they indicate that existing sacred areas protect a variety of habitat niches and increase avian diversity at multiple spatial scales. As population growth and rapid economic development continues throughout the Himalayas, sacred sites are an important opportunity for biological conservation at the local, landscape and regional scales.

Our bird research activities in Shangrila attracted the attention of many local residents and visiting tourists. Often people are surprised to hear that there is such great bird diversity and abundance, even in forests close to the city. There are no existing resources, such as local field guides or basic information, about the birds of Shangrila. Thus, we produced a 'Handbook to the Common Birds of Shangrila'. The book is in Chinese, English and Tibetan, and is especially designed for local people and visiting Chinese and international tourists. It features photos, paintings, Tibetan folk talkes, descriptions, and a CD with bird songs of the 70 most common birds around Shangrila, and maps of the best locations to go birding. The book is in print, and 3000 copies will be distributed to local schools and businesses, where they will be sold at a very inexpensive price (e.g. $3).

The Chinese government’s primary strategy for economic development of NW Yunnan is tourism. Over 3.8 million Chinese tourists arrived to the region in 2007, up from 1.2 million in 2001. The tourists come primarily from the wealthier, more developed eastern regions of China, specifically to appreciate the natural beauty and high biodiversity of this region. A growing appreciation of birds is at the forefront of the environmental movement in China. This research, and the environmental education book that resulted, could contribute to the growing movement to protect nature in NW Yunnan, as well as contribute to bird appreciation throughout China.
